text: Greetings and welcome to the January 21st, 2020 meeting of the Seattle city council.
I am Lisa Herbold, president pro Tem of the Council.
Will the clerk, please call role?
[roll call]
Thank you.
First on the agenda is presentations.
There are no presentations today.
Next up is the approval of the minutes.
The minutes of the January 6 2020 city council meetings have been reviewed.
If there is no objection, the minutes will be signed.
Hearing no objections, the minutes are being signed.
I would like to recognize that we have been joined by Councilmember Pedersen.
Next up, we have the adoption of the calendar.
If there is no objection, the referral calendar will be adopted.
Seeing and hearing no objection, the introduction and referral calendar is adopted.
Next, we have approval of the agenda.
If there is no objection, the agenda will be adopted.
Hearing no objection, the agenda is adopted.
Next, we have on the agenda, public comment, and public comment will be accepted for 20 minutes.
I am going to do a quick review of the number of people signed up.
Given that we have 51 people signed up for public comment, public comment today will be limited to 1.5 minutes of public comment.
If the Speaker's comment exceeds 1.5 minutes, the clerk will turn off the microphone.
If we still have people signed up to speak at the end of the 20 minutes, I will consult with my colleagues and see if we can extend the public comment period.
Speakers are asked to begin their comments by identifying themselves, and the specific agenda item they would like to speak to.
With that, I'm going to begin reading the names into the record, and I will read two names at a time.
There are multiple microphones.
If you could line up at both, as I read your name, I would appreciate it.
That way, we can move things more smoothly.
We will start with Chikaru Sheila, representing a group, followed by Frizhana Kahn.
How many minutes for a group?
Three minutes for a group.
Okay.
My name is Chikaru Sheila.
I study economic development in Southeast Asia.
My role is to clarify confusions about the Nrcrcaa on 3116.
I am a professor, but speak privately as an Indian resident, not for the University or its units.
Part of the justifications offered is that India needs to handle a massive problem of illegal Migratio.

The Indian census indicates this is not the case, but in the interest of time, I will look to the way the National register can be used to strip citizenship even from people born in India, and have lived there their whole lives.
Unlike the United States, India does not provide automatic citizenship based on birth.
Of the three modes by which one can become a citizen or Naturalization.
Changes of law have made it easier to seek belonging for religious orientation and harder to seek it based on birth.
For a child born in India today, up to two generations of proof of ancestry is required to establish birth.
Such records would be difficult for many of us to produce.
They are an immense hurdle for most of the population, many of whom cannot read, do not own former property, don't have bank accounts, and have been poorly served by departments that serve documents.
Indian Muslims are already average poorer than others, and will have a hard time compared to Hindus and others, who will be granted approval through the Nrcrcaa.
This is the context in which it would be more difficult for members of one legend, Islam, to access Naturalization for gaining citizenship.
The ca says, if you are a member of a major religion, recognize that is not Islam, it will become easier and quicker for you to become a naturalized immigrant if you came from Pakistan or Bangladesh.

Muslims can go elsewhere by virtue of their religion, according to theory, but this does not merely apply to people looking to cross the border, but to Muslims who have lived in India for generations and face additional discrimination on the basis of their religion.
The explanation of the majority religions and for why Sri Lanka and Myanmar have seen religious persecution are not covered by the Caa.
The Caa has been compared to the Lautenberg amendment in the U.S. which provides a fast track for some religions, for refugee status.
The difference is the Lautenberg amendment only applies to refugee status, and the function of a legal environment guaranteed birthright citizenship.
The effect of the Caa and Nrcrcaa together results in dissemination.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Following Frizhana Kahn, Sannah alum.
I am here to support all of the religions of the nation today.
Caa benefits Hindus, discrimination, and refugees from Afghanistan, Pakistan, Bangladesh, who sought refuge in India, explicitly leaving out Muslims.
The Rohingya of Myanmar have faced Genocide.
This has outraged not only Muslims, but all of those Indian citizens who believe in the secular Constitution.
While we support India being a welcoming country for refugees, we do not want it to be discriminatory.
The first step should be for India to rectify various U.S.
Entities, like the global compact for migration.
Caa, when you combine with MRC, the Minister of India has said, multiple times, the nation of citizenship is going to be a lethal weapon.
The NRC has already been implemented, which left 2 million people out, and out of those 2 million people, I think almost 1.5 million are basically Hindus.
To rescue those Hindus, to save their own lives, they came up with Caa, so what's going to happen is those half-million people who are Muslims, now they have no place to go to.
Even though the P.A.
Of India has said it is not attention centered, there are some incentives already.
28 people have already died in them.
I cannot believe it.
We are talking about, you know, like another possible holocaust.
We have all seen the history.
How it's going to happen.
The 2 million people who did not make it into NRC.
Those people didn't necessarily have documents.
There was a family who didn't make it into the NRC who had a President of India in the family.
There was a farmer who was a Muslim and she did not make it to NRC.
These are not the people who are illiterate or poor, who wouldn't bring up the documents to prove their citizenship.
Thank you.
Your time is up.
[Applause]
Following Sannah alum, we have Arul Mosey.
Good afternoon.
I am here to support both resolutions.
I have been living in the Seattle area for a loan 11 years now.
I love the Pacific Northwest him about how all of us Seattleites are gearing up against Caa and NRC.
I am not going to talk a lot about it because a lot has been spoken on Caa.
I want to say about the way Indian government is implementing Caa and NRC is bound to create havoc.
We are already seeing glances over.
There is a countrywide protest going on in India.
People from all walks of life are joining them.
There are women from New Delhi, which is the National Capitol.
They've been there for many days.
We are seeing clear contempt of these nationwide protests.
There have been cases where students have been brutally beaten up by police.
Some of the students ended up losing their fingers, and there have been cases where a student was blinded in one of his eyes.
There are cases where students were picked up, stripped naked, and put in police custody.
We have also seen Muslim minorities are being targeted.
Their shops, their homes.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Arul Mosey and then Charmin Hassan.
My name is Arul Mosey.
I've lived in Redmond.
I was born into a backward community, designated as Hindu into one of the middle layers of the greater nation.
This community was barred from education but held some land, so that made my father the first graduate of the entire ancestry.
That made me a collective privilege holding person, who comes and speaks in front of you.
As the cast discrimination layers go down, as to food, shelter, and education, it's a painful struggle, not only for a respectful wife, but even for a respectful death.
This is extremely difficult for communities, and certain types to get a hold of the legal documents that are demanded.
People like me who were born in the 80s, in the rural part of India, do not even have good certificates because the birth certification of the government was not right.

To insist again, the majority of the population was denied education too demanding documents like birth certificate and land ownership for citizenship would not be very accessible for the Non- Landowning, underprivileged, and marginalized communities.
The NRC process rests the citizenship romance of the caste privilege bureaucrats, who have time, again, to take their money forward.
We hear that a Council members here might hold the resolution for today, and not allow voting today.
It is Disrespectful for the people who made time to come forward to ask for the resolution today.
I urge the Council to vote today, yes, and please.
Think you.
[Applause]
Following Charmin Hassan, we have Dipa Shivarajan.
We are going to come up as a group.
Okay.
3 1/2 minutes if there's actually a group.
They are coming up.
Thank you.
Termite.
Cockroach.
Illegal.
Infiltrator.
These are the words that my people have been branded by the ruling party of India.
When I hear these words, a part of me dies.
I ache for the conditions of my people.
They need protection from a state that only wants to exterminate us.
I am a Muslim, and as I hear these words, I hear most poignantly, the drumbeat of Genocide.

Bengalis as a people have survived one Genocides in our region, from the colonial and Post-Famine in Bengal, where over 3 million people died from starvation, to the violence of partition, to the independence from Pakistan, which led to another 3 million people, and over 400,000 women raped.
This was the largest incidents of rape I a Genocidal level in history.
The time to act is now.
I am here to give my urgent testimony and urge the city Council to vote on this today.
We cannot postpone a vote.
If we postpone a vote, that means we are giving power to the right-wing people who wanted to quell dissent, and silence the minorities across South Asia that are fighting for our lives right now.
Detention camps are being built right now.
My name is Charmin Hassan.
I am a political director of a national organization called E quality LABS.
We represent Southeast Asians across the Diaspora.
The importance of this city council passing this resolution cannot be overstated.
When Genocidal campaigns begin, one important intervention is International condemnation.
We see you as a body of people that will stand on the right side of history.
We really need you to pass this resolution today.
Because of this resolution, Seattle has a unique opportunity to leave the moral consensus, and the global outcry against the Caa.
In light of these concerns, we hold that this will be an assurance that the entirety of the South Asian community is safe in Seattle.

We relive the old horrors, and it's vital to know that Seattle is a sanctuary for South Asian- American communities that are standing in solidarity with millions who are protesting the citizenship amendment act, the NRC, and the NRA.
The Caa is terrifying.
There is absolutely no grounds by which anyone of conscience can support it.
The law creates an unconstitutional Religious- based criteria to grant citizenship to select immigrants.
The Caa is an integral part of the Multi-Governance process of creating a stateless population.
It explicitly targets Muslims, and will impact all the marble communities.
I urge you on behalf of millions of my people, to pass this resolution today.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Following Dipa Shivarajan, we have Sannah alum seven.
I am a member of the Seattle Lgbtq Commission.
I have a letter stating our support for 31296.
When the multi government updated the National Registry of citizens in a Psalm, over 2 million people left out of the register, at least 2000 were Transgender.

Lgbtq people are uniquely vulnerable to the high burden to verify their citizenship because they may be estranged from their families or only have documentation that lists the sex they were assigned at birth.
Because of the citizenship amendment act, these people are in danger of being rendered stateless in India.
In Kashmir, the Indian security forces have implemented martial law and a communications blockade for months on end.
Lgbtq Kashmiris have been cut off nationally and abroad.
The reason we have taken a stance on this is because we recognize human rights abuses in India are a blow to marginalized people everywhere, including in Seattle.
Muslims face discrimination and violence in Seattle.
Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, and Sikhs face dissemination and violence in Seattle.

Bypassing this today, council would send a strong message that discrimination based on race, caste, nationality, religion, gender, sexual orientation, disability, or class are not tolerated here in Seattle, and Seattle stands for human rights locally and globally.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Following Sikhs, we have Prishat.
I am Ibrahim MOGUL here to support both organizations today.
While we support India as a welcoming country for refugees, we do not want it to be discriminatory.
I'm here to urge all of you Councilmembers to vote unanimously and approve this resolution.
Why?
We observed an okay day yesterday.
Dr. Martin Luther King said, injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.
We are tied in a single garment of destiny.
Whatever affects one directly affects all of us indirectly.
Let me give you some data about, you know, what injustice is happening in India.
I will go back to 2007.
The Indian society right now has been discriminating against religious basis.
It is again infiltrated by the government, and Rss, which is the Extremist right-wing organization in India.
Back in 2007, 8 out of 10 times, they refused to sell me a home because I am a Muslim.
Imagine if they pass this law.
They are given power to all of the bureaucrats to decide on what paper basis, and religion basis, the citizenship will be decided.
Itwill be chaos and another Genocide.
I urge all of the Councilmembers to approve this resolution today.
We are hoping for the justice.
You will make my dream speech of Martin Luther King Jr. true today by taking these steps, so I urge all of you.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Following Prishat Nima, we have Mina Kumar.
I am here to support both resolutions.
I hope you will vote today.
While we support India becoming a welcoming country for refugees, we don't want it to be discriminatory.
I was born into an upper caste Hindu family.
This means my family always had the privilege of access to education, documentation, and our existence had wealth and power.
Coming to America is one such privilege, which is why in the caste of India, it's upside down and overwhelmingly upper caste.
I am from the top 10% of the country where 80% of people suffer deprivation of material wealth.
That means the large policies in India do not affect my family in any way.
I have the privilege of watching the manifestation of these laws and policies.
Show your documents, and nothing bad will happen to you.
Why would I oppose a government policy that will privilege my kind by giving them more voice in the system?
I would guess light each one of these speakers before me.
I would try to trick the Council by saying the Caa's attempt is to help neighboring countries.
I would even show you figures from 1941 to 2020 without telling you there were mass human migrations between this time.
But I want to be a better human being.
That's why I want everybody to support this resolution.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Following Mina Kumar, we have Archana Sunyo.
As an Indian, I grew up watching conflict in cylinder.
I am still heartbroken about the genocide.
With that knowledge, looking at the current situation in India, the genocide is a particularly a phenomenon of the modern era.
It's built on nationalism.
I am afraid it's going to happen soon in India.
Look at the NRC.
It deliberately discriminate Muslim by religion, and refugees living in India for more than three decades, and making it harder or impossible for them to obtain citizenship in India.
It reminds me of 1948, the citizenship act that discriminated against Aboriginals.
In cylinder, and divided the people of Selinka as single use.
Dividing the publishing into dominant Hindu and supported Muslim group.
I want to insists the systemic segregation's are one of the major drivers.
Dehumanizing people reminds me of how people in Sri Lanka [Indiscernible]. Other attributes of genocide, with the physical extermination of groups.
It's all there.
Please Cover-Up up.
I urge you to support these resolutions and stop India stepping into Genocide.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Following Archana Sunyo, we have Rahm Dixon.
Thank you for giving me this opportunity to voice my opinion on 31266.
This Council is being misled by false information.
The passage of this resolution will be received as bigotry against Hindus, Christians, and Sikhs.
First, not an ethics violation, but this Council to deliberate on matters of another country with public resources--Seattle has a long list of its own issues to work on.
Over 12,000 who are homeless.

Neither will strip 200 million Muslims of citizenship as you have falsely claimed.
Caa, in fact, gives citizenship to 37,000 persecuted minorities as I listed earlier.
No different than our own Buttenberg amendment, which was recently touted by representative Jayapal.
Nrc has not even been implemented yet.
The government has an exhaustive way to prove citizenship, not just a father's birth certificate.
On what basis are you spreading these lies?
The Caa is a law in India.
Your illogical, be slick laws will not change the law in India.
If anything will jeopardize bilateral trade, especially with Washington, India was the temperature largest export market and 16th largest source of imported goods.
Please Cover-Up up.
I am speaking as a group.
In the future, let me know in advance.
Just to be clear, if you are speaking as a group, you forgo your opportunity to speak again, so any folks, I will need to take the name --
They are not.
I apologize for that.
India was the 10th largest export market and the 16th largest source of exported goods for Washington alone.
Do you really want to mess with this based on lies?
I have provided each of you with information on the Caa and NRC.
But please, stop.
The Online petition has been signed.
I've provided you with information on NRC Ncaa, which will be given to you after the meeting.
The Online petition against this resolution, signed by over 3000 Indian Americans, was Emailed to all of the Councilmembers.
Mess Councilmember Sawant, your apathy towards those 37,000 persecuted minorities is alarming, to say the least.
God bless America.
[Applause]
At this point, we have exceeded the team allotted for public comment.
I am going to consult with my colleagues, and look to extend the time for public comment.
I would ask that we not clap and between speakers, so we can hear from more people.
We have only heard from 10 people who have signed up to speak.
We have a total of 51 people.

In order to get through the list, I would like a request, your cooperation, in making sure that we stick to the time limits, which are now going to be one minute for individuals, since again, assuming my colleagues agreed to extend the Timeline.
One minute for individuals.
Two minutes for a group.
If you can identify--I know sometimes, people are coming up as a group.
I don't know that that means you wish to speak as a group, so if you could let me know in advance, I would appreciate that, as well.
And, I would like to propose another 30 minutes to do public comment if folks agree.
Is that right?
Seeing no objections, we will extend the Timeline to 3:00 for 30 minutes of public testimony.
We are speaking as a group.
Thank you.
You are Rahm Dixon followed by Javeed Sakhander.
I speak to you today urging you to vote against Councilmember Sawant's resolution condemning the CEA law.
I am a citizen of the United States.
I Immigrated to this country in 1970.
I have lived all over the nation and I'm proud to call Seattle home for the past 22 years.
Even after all of these years, I visit India two to three times a year.
I have friends, family, and I stay in touch.
I am fully aware of what's happening in India today.
Well it's absolutely important for our city, state, and country to be welcoming to all regardless of race, religion, or creed, the resolution is misplaced and based on distortions.
India was violently Partitioned in 1947, but despite that, adopted a pluralistic, Multiethnic, Multi-Religious framework.
The other countries created as a result of India's partition adopted Islam as their national religion.
They relegated their citizens of any other faith other than Islam to second-class status.
They were persecuted, discriminated in all spheres of life, including conversions, denying educational, and professional opportunities, and in many instances brutally murdered.
I am not even going to talk about Afghanistan.
We all know what the Taliban did to the minorities there.
The citizenship amendment act that Councilmember Sawant resolution condemns was passed by the Indian Parliament.
It is additive.
It gives citizenship to persecuted refugees, and minorities from other countries.
The Dreamers from those countries.
I support Streamers everywhere on this planet.
Those refugees deserve no less.
This law is not about stripping anyone of their citizenship.
I stand with Streamers everywhere.
I stand with the India Caa law because it provides a path to citizenship that we are also fighting in this country for the Dreamers who live here.
Stand with the Dreamers.
Support the Dreamers.
But please car wrap up.
I really hope the Council REJECTS this proposition.
Thank you.
[Applause]

Dear Councilmembers, thank you for taking the time today.
Have spoken here last week when we proposed this resolution.
I am super proud of the steps the city is taking to announce the citizenship act as well as the National Registry in India.
As the amnesty International report that was published recently, details these laws, when implemented, cause significant damage, pain, and suffering.
As one of my previous speakers said, around 30 people have already died in detention camps.

You can imagine when something like this is implemented across India.
While these acts are created to divide people, the people of India, as you can see, are uniting.
Today, you don't see people someone faith.
You have people from all faiths here.
Thank you very much.
I appreciate this resolution.
Thank you.
If we continue to clap between speakers, we will not be able to hear from everybody, okay?
I respectfully request that you do not clap between speakers, so we can hear from everybody.
Asma Suka Shaik, followed by Iftar Karr.
Azmuk?

Iftar Karr.
That's me.

There is people of all religions and Castes opposed to this citizenship amendment act because it is discriminatory, goes against the secular fabric of the country, and threatens the culture, language, and traditions of the indigenous people.
Six students died in police fire, in December 2019.

The Prime Minister, and the home Minister keeps claiming that there are no detention centers in the state.
But there are already six or seven detention centers.
The National citizen process is very flawed and was conducted in --
Please car wrap up.
I implore all Councilmembers to supports Councilmember Sawant's measure.

We are part of a group.
So, you are speaking as a group?
You can take her name off.
What was your name?
Lava Nariti.

Broke into.

For a second, forget about everything.

Hindus, Buddhists, Christians, across Pakistan.
Even the you and report says the same thing.
Show me one report that says Pakistan is treating their minorities nice.
Nobody.
Pakistan reduced their minorities from 15% to 1.5% in 50 years.

Is are prosecuted people, feeling their loss.

They are Feuring those countries, and coming to India.
These people, just 35,000 people.

Does that make us hypocrites?
Think about that when you vote.
Also, this resolution is a humanitarian resolution.
It should not stop anybody from supporting any humanitarian work.
Also, there were so many laws, --
Please car wrap up.
Thank you so much.

Amaya Shakar?
Ragav Kashuk followed by Sagatha Rahmi.
My colleagues covered a lot of important points.
I want to stick to three or four points.
I completely support the resolutions Councilmember Sawant is proposing today.
There are a couple of points that were brought up.
One was about India helping refugees.
We totally support that.
We want India to have refugees, as well.
However, we feel that the first attempt to do that is to have India ratify the yuan convention, for example, and not past a discriminatory law like the Caa.
The second thing is about NRC, detention centers.
We heard a lot of stories about detention centers.

That was their words.
Not mine.
I would urge you to pay attention to the human rights violation as observed not only by personal stories but what amnesty International says.
The other points I want to make our --
Please car wrap up.
It.
A connection to local issues.
I want to point out that I would urge everyone to vote on this issue today because we have so many people who came, who took time off from their work to come here.
[Applause]
Aye followed by Bahkti.
I am seeing familiar faces making up this group.
Maybe, someone else who hasn't been here?
I am here to read a statement.
This is from an Award-Winning journalist.
He has written mess and sent it to the Council, but I want to bring this up in statement today.
My name is Palagumi Sinot.
This is my 25th year as a journalist.
I have not seen protests of the nature and scale we have now seen in defense of some of the most important values of Indian democracy.
The Caa is not just about an attack on India's Constitution.
It is about the replacement of it.
A first very major step.
It Dislodges one of its most important foundations by bringing in a Religious-Based section that is the antithesis of this secular, and Democratic Constitution.
It does that by violating the basic principle of equality before law, excluding one religious minority from its provisions.
It undermines the entire edifice of the Constitution in the process.
Conversely, the protesters on the streets are doing much more than resisting one constitutional amendment.
All of them articulated that we are not.
They are out there in defense of the most basic values of any Republican Constitution and democracy.
That is liberty, equality, and fraternity.
The Bjp government should shock but not surprised us.
As early as 1947, the parent organization of the Bjp had announced about to adopt an Indian Constitution.
They wanted it to be replaced from a Brahmin text that codified extreme caste and gender oppression.
Now in power, they will indeed got the Constitution based on equality before law, something they've always despised.
I urge you to vote, and support Councilmember Sawant's resolution today.
All of us have taken time out.
Some of us have flown in from out of town.
I urge you to not postpone the vote, and vote on this today.
Thank you.
[Applause]
Following Bahkti Joki.
I have come here from my home, my work because I saw in the city council hall, people are speaking extravagant lies, preparing a completely distorted view of India.
I am no reporter, no generalist, nothing, but when I see people speaking lies, have to come and tell you to check this.

What happened to your minorities?

Us versus them.

I am the chair of the Indo- American forum.
I am going to speak against the Caa resolution brought by Councilmember Sawant.
Just for your information, Councilmember Sawant does not take away the citizenship of Andy Indian citizen, including 200 million Muslim citizens.
Two thirds come to my mind.
Either the Councilmember is totally ignorant about the matters or falling prey to the misinformation campaign initiated by some Western interests, which I can see here.
I emphasize again that Caa has no implication on the existing citizens of India.
Irrespective of their religious faith car and belief.
For a cosmopolitan city see like Seattle, which has a history of harmony, the resolution may act as a divisive force.
Resolutions also have a detrimental effect in the overall context of into American relations.
I request that the Councilmembers reject this resolution, please.
Thank you.
[Applause]
We have Alak mother.
Slegers item University District of Seattle for the last 15 years.
I am working as a physician.
I strongly oppose 3126.
My arguments are as follows.
One, the resolution is out of the Purview of the mission, and function of the Seattle city council.
Two, the resolution is not called for.
It is a soft missile attack from the government of Seattle against the government of India.
And has definite consequences of damaging the harmony and peace of the citizens, not only of Seattle, but of India.
Number three.
It is inappropriate to bundle multiple acts and issues in one resolution.
Number four.

The resolution has serious and overwhelming color as the proponents of the resolution are giving their concern about the Muslims in India by using $250 million with variations of $50 million in error.
They would not allow the counting of the population in India.
Thank you very much.
I have lived in Seattle for the last 44 years.
I would like to present my views against the resolution that Counilmember Sawant has brought for the citizenship amendment.
For your information, Caa does not take away the citizenship of any Indian citizen, including 200 million Muslim citizens.

I strongly believe, either Councilmember Sawant is totally ignorant about facts or being Misinformed by certain vested interests . I emphasize again, there is no implication on the existing citizens of India irrespective of their religious Ãšfaith or belief.
Caa is going to help all citizens, not just the minorities of India.
